text: MOSP 2011 Blue Joshua Nichols-Barrer Sums & Products 1. Let n be a positive integer. Evaluate n∑ k=1 ∑ 1≤i1<···<ik≤n 2 k (i1 + 1)(i2 + 1) · · · (ik + 1) . 2. Let k be an odd positive integer, and let x be an arbitrary real number. Prove that tan(kx) = (−1) k−1 2 k−1∏ j=0 tan ( x − jπ k ) 3. Prove that for any positive integer n, n! is a divisor of n−1∏ k=0(2 n − 2 k). 4. Let f (n) be a function deﬁned on the set of positive integers such that f (1) = 2 and f (n + 1) = (f (n)) 2 − f (n) + 1 for every positive integer n. Prove that for n = 2, 3, . . ., 1 − 1 22n−1 < 1 f (1) + 1 f (2) + · · · + 1 f (n) < 1 − 1 22n . 5. Let n be an integer greater than 1, and let A be a set of real numbers with less than n elements. Suppose that 20, 2 1, 2 2, . . . , 2 n−1 can be written as the sum of distinct elements in A. Prove that A contains at least one negative number. 6. Prove that for every positive integer n, n∑ k=1 1 k( n k) = 1 2n−1 n∑ k=1 k odd (n k) k . 7. For a nonnegative integer N , let u(N ) denote the number of ones in N when expressed in binary (so that for example u(10) = u(10102) = 2). Let m, n ≥ 0 be integers and k ≥ mn a third integer. Express 2k−1∑ i=0 (−1) u(i)(( i m ) n ) in closed form. 1 MOSP 2011 Blue Joshua Nichols-Barrer 8. For a ﬁnite set S of numbers, let |S| denote its cardinality, σ(S) the sum of its elements and π(S) the product. Suppose that S is a ﬁnite set of nonnegative integers, and let N ≥ σ(S) be a nonnegative integer. Prove that ∑ T ⊆S(−1) |T |(N − σ(T ) |S| ) = π(S). 9. Given a positive integer n, express the sum 1 ( 2n 1 ) − 1 ( 2n 2 ) + 1 (2n 3 ) − · · · − 1 ( 2n 2n−2) + 1 ( 2n 2n−1) in closed form. 10. Let a1, a2, . . . , an be real numbers satisfying the system of equations a1 2 + a2 3 + · · · + an n + 1 = 4 3 , a1 3 + a2 4 + · · · + an n + 2 = 4 5 ... ... ... a1 n + 1 + a2 n + 2 + · · · + an 2n = 4 2n + 1 . Express ∑n i=1 ai 2i+1 in closed form. 11. Let S = {x1, x2, . . . , xk+ℓ} be a (k + ℓ)-element set of real numbers contained in the interval [0, 1]; k and ℓ are positive integers. A k-element subset A ⊂ S is called nice if             1 k ∑ xi∈A xi − 1 ℓ ∑ xj ∈S\A xj             ≤ k + ℓ 2kℓ . Prove that the number of nice subsets is at least 2 k + ℓ ( k + ℓ k ) . 12. Prove that for every pair m, k of natural numbers, m has a unique representation in the form m = (ak k ) + ( ak−1 k − 1 ) + · · · + ( at t ) , where ak > ak−1 > · · · > at ≥ t ≥ 1. 2 MOSP 2011 Blue Joshua Nichols-Barrer 13. Let n be a positive integer and let a1 ≤ a2 ≤ · · · ≤ an and b1 ≤ b2 ≤ · · · ≤ bn be two nondecreasing sequences of real numbers such that a1 + · · · + ai ≤ b1 + · · · + bi for every i = 1, 2, . . . , n − 1 and a1 + a2 + · · · + an = b1 + b2 + · · · + bn. Suppose that for any real number m, the number of pairs (i, j) with ai − aj = m equals the number of pairs (k, ℓ) with bk − bℓ = m. Prove that ai = bi for i = 1, 2, . . . , n. 14. Let A and B be two sets each with n positive real numbers, such that the sum of the elements in A equals the sum of the elements in B. Show that there exists an n × n array of nonnegative real numbers such that (a) The set of row sums is A; (b) The set of column sums is B; (c) There are at least (n − 1)2 + |A ∩ B| zeroes in the array. 15. Let n be a given integer greater than 1, and let a1, a2, . . . , an be real numbers (not all zero). Prove that the following statements are equivalent: (a) There exist integers 0 < x1 < x2 < · · · < xn such that a1x1 + a2x2 + · · · + anxn ≥ 0. (b) There exists k, 1 ≤ k ≤ n, such that ak + ak+1 + · · · + an > 0. 16. (Tricky) Let P be a convex polygon in the plane. A real number is assigned to each point in the plane so that the sum of the numbers assigned to the vertices of any polygon similar to P is equal to 0. Prove that all the assigned numbers are equal to 0. 17. Let S denote the set of rational numbers in the interval (0, 1). Determine, with proof, if there exists a subset T of S such that every element of S can be uniquely written as a sum of ﬁnitely many distinct elements in T . 3
